content: I would like to ask if this solution time can be adjusted. Reading the inputs alone is 3s. This is also true for a whole lot of other puzzles outside of this scope. There should be a difference in just reading the inputs and actual time for calculations.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i‚Äôm accepting this contribution because I genuinely loved the puzzle. It feels original, clever, and really fun to play, with clear rules and a satisfying challenge. The difficulty is well balanced for a ‚Äúhard‚Äù game, and the overall design makes the solving process engaging from start to finish. :)
good

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Another great solo game, I had fun solving it.
Lots of tests/validators like always and the statement and rules are clear and easy to understand with an implementation that requires proper optimization for the hardest tests.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: What an incredibly fun puzzle! I‚Äôve tackled many logic puzzles in recent years, but the reasoning this one demands feels unique and especially satisfying. The visuals are sharp, the instructions are clear, and the difficulty curve is just right. With five test cases and five validators at the hardest level, the coverage should be fantastic for any algorithm. A great blend of logic and search for solving these magnetic boards!

I only have one suggestion. I would consider changing all the "Missing..." test cases and validators to "Expert 1, Expert 2, Expert 3, Expert 4 and Expert 5." I feel like I understand that you are changing the grid layouts so people have to have more robust algorithms that don't just get lucky. I always appreciate multiple test cases at the hardest level to really test how thorough I've been with my solution. However, I've looked at the names for a while now and they don't help me understand the difference between the test cases. They just seem like 5 Expert level test cases / validators to me.

I'm solving everything except #21 100% with logic, so other than this one minor suggestion, I'm completely ready to go! This is a super fun puzzle and it is well put together!

- Fixed "Missing Hints Top (Test 10)" such that is doesn't match "Missing Hints Left (Test 9)"
- Changed BFS tag to DFS (since task is to find solution ASAP not find "best/shortest" solution)
- Added Heuristic search tag
- Updated Intro Replay to match harder testcase
- Implemented my own solution in C++ (around 300 LOC)

Game is imune to pure recursion, so player has to combine multiple concepts therefor HARD difficulty. Marking game as READY
Added imune-to-pure-recursion testcases. I still need to implement my own solution. Also moving to HARD, since straightforward usage of well known algorithms just isn't enough
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
yo

I like the new time limits! I'd like to see 2 more Impossible level test cases and 2 more Impossible level validators. If I remove all logical, problem-space reduction, I still solve all test cases and all validators, EXCEPT the last validator. Passing all test cases while still failing a validator can be super frustrating. Adding a couple more Impossible level puzzles helps reduce any luck factor in the coder's backtracking setup. In my case the Impossible test case just happens to allow a quick solution for my backtracking algorithm (I got lucky) while the validator does not. 

With logic added back in, nothing takes over 20 ms.
Time limit for turn 1 is 7.5 sec. I think 2 sec is more than enough.
Nice puzzle, but the ref has a bug that accepts a board filled with wooden blocks

I found this puzzle harder than Pips, but nowhere near as hard as Battleship Solitaire. I started with Algorithm X, but I could only solve the first three test cases without timing out. I then switched to logical, problem-space reduction and that led to a full solution.

I think the test case progression is very good, but I will put some more thought into it. With this puzzle (very different than Battleship Solitaire) a little bit of problem-space reduction cascades quickly into smaller problems that Algorithm X easily handles.

I will play around with this puzzle and then circle back with more comments.

Rules
* Consider changing "north" and "south" to "negative" and "positive" respectively.

* Please delete "required".

* Please change "on predefined cells" to "in predefined two-cell regions, which can be oriented horizontally or vertically".

* Do all cells on the board need to be filled (either with magnets or with wooden blocks)? If so, please make that requirement clearer by rewriting the last point as:
The board must be fully covered by magnets and wooden blocks. Each wooden block, like a magnet, occupies a predefined two-cell region, and is marked with <const>x</const>.

Initial input
* Line 3 & Line 5: Please change "row i" to "each row, from top to bottom".

* Line 4 & Line 6: Please change "column i" to "each column, from left to right".

Turn input
* Please delete "Next".

* Consider changing "south" and "north" to "positive" and "negative" respectively.

* Please add ", excluding <const>x</const>" after "a-z".

* Please change "magnet cell pairs" to "two-cell regions".

* Please change "same magnet" to "same region".

Turn output
* Is (0, 0) the top-left? If so, please add:
The board's top-left position is [0, 0].

Cases
* For each of the board sizes (6 x 5, 8 x 7 and 10 x 9), please rotate the boards in at least one pair of cases so that width < height.

* Update the constraints accordingly after the above change.

Console messages / Viewer / Further review on cases
* I'll review these later.

Thanks.
Perfect for me! Good game!
Validators is the key of good games. Not enough for this one. X
Are you going to include neutral dominoes?
I don't think it's necessary. Or should I?
That's why "In progress" ;)

Given your high user level, it'd be awesome if you could help with some deeper testing on new contributions. For example, another CodinGamer and I noticed that the current referee passed a board filled entirely of wooden blocks, which clearly shouldn't happen. Your input could really help us catch things like that. Many thanks!
Statement fixed... I'll see what I can do about board rotations. Board is currently fixated to landscape, so it might take some time. Thanks.
Harder than Pips? I found this one simplest of them all... Maybe don't rely on AlgorithmX on every puzzle you see :D
TY. I known about the issue, just didnt have time to resolve it :)

It fails because there are too many unspecified rows at the top of the board. So the search space grows too fast too soon if placing without any move ordering.

I plan to introduce 3 more testcases+validators to test scenarios with unspecified rows/columns mostly at left/top/right/bottom part of the board covering problem you mentioned... I believe bigger boards shouldn't be necessary for this puzzle

Cases
* "Missing Hints Left" (Test 9) and "Missing Hints Top" (Test 10) are the same ü§î

Thanks.
I see "Expert" is the wrong word, but you know what I mean.

What language is that? I believe timer starts after 1st input is read. And if reading input takes 3seconds then there is something seriously wrong about your code. It's simple standard input/output. No way it takes that long
The language is C#. The code is not seriously wrong, this has been observed with many puzzles and I made special timers to see this.

Names changed to "Impossible #"

> I'm solving everything except #21 100% with logic
Not sure what your logic is, but #21 is just vertically flipped #20. So this one is on you :D

Every testcase has its validator match by flipping/rotating.

But still pretty impressive to pull this one without any search. Maybe I'm just too lazy

>> Not sure what your logic is, but #21 is just vertically flipped #20. So this one is on you :D

You almost had me on this one! I'm looking at #21 vs #23. The grid has just been rotated 90 degrees. The clues are all the same, but horizontal clues have been rotated CCW while vertical clues have been rotated CW. So, same clues and same board configuration, but clues are juggled ever so slightly resulting in completely different solutions. Brilliant! üí•
Thanks to the new cases I've found a bug in my code, good addition :D

Initial input
* Line 5: Please add ")" after "bottom".

‚Ä¶and I'll wait for the revised cases before I review again. Thanks!

Rotated 3 testcases and 3 validators. Fixed line 5.
I got timeout on last validator, but solved it locally under 3 seconds. I will mark the game as ready after solving it.
Please don't mark the game as ready so soon üòÖ I haven't done my thorough testing yet.
sorry boss üò¨ :D

I'm not the boss üôà

And I read that @Timinator might want to share some additional comments too, so let's wait for his input as well üòâ

:thumbsup: got it working...

Last validator has more hints at the bottom of the board. So starting from top might be too slow. Maybe I should prepare more testcases to cover exactly this problem (most hints at left/top/right/bottom)

Great!

And good idea. Ensure adequate and balanced coverage of different scenarios.

Constraints
* Please update the first two constraints.

Turn input
* Please add "which are unoccupied" after "two-cell regions".

* After placing a wooden block, the input of the following turns doesn't show x. For example, in "Simple" (Test 1), I got the following as my input even when I had placed wooden blocks at various locations:

-+-+-+
+-+-HI
-+-+HI
+-KK-+
MM-+OO

Referee
* Printing "0 0 y" gives me a timeout message instead of the invalid input error. (I guess you should use || instead of && for the relevant error checking condition.)

* The game crashed when I printed "3 4 ".

* The winning message doesn't appear in the console when I pass a case.

* I passed "Simple" (Test 1) even though I was short of the required poles, like this:

-+-+-+
+-+-HI
-+-+HI
+-KKLL
MM-+OO

or this:

-+-+-+
+-F-HI
-+F+HI
+-KK-+
MM-+OO

* Oh wait! I could even pass the case by filling the board with wooden blocks ONLY.

(Who said the puzzle could be marked as Ready? ü§™ )

Thanks.
Oh my... I've added those stupid wooden tiles and broke the referee completely :D should be fixed

Thank you for fixing the referee. It seems to be working correctly now.

I just have one small suggestion: could we standardise the wording in the error messages? Currently, one of them uses "character" while the others use "symbol". For consistency, please change "character" to "symbol".

Current messages:

‚Ä¢ Empty output; space separated 'x', 'y' and '+/-/x' character expected.

‚Ä¢ Space separated 'x', 'y' and '+/-/x' symbol expected.

‚Ä¢ Invalid output. Symbol should be one of +/-/x.

Thanks again for your help!
I think you should. I played several games a while back by hand and the neutral pieces seemed important. It also seems like they add some extra complexity.
Added "wooden" blocks :)
